values: This is kind of easy: contact with friends and family is what cheers me up.   In some respects it has also been a bit of a "blocker" as many people have said to me that I need to become more comfortable with my own company, but I've always been a social person, and when I'm down there is nothing like personal interraction to pick me up!

I'd build a planet, within reach of Earth, where everyone actually cared about the welfare of everyone else there, and because of that wasn't focussed on how much money and stuff they could acquire in their lifetime.   It would also be a planet willing to take as many refugees and/or immigrants as wished to come there.

Then everyone who wants to live in a world like that could leave Earth and go there, and this planet we live on would be only full of cockheads who were power-hungry, money-hungry, and uncaring.

And they'd all deserve each other.

During the last couple of weeks I've been regularly reading about how impressed everybody has been after seeing the new Leonardo DiCaprio film Inception.   I saw it tonight and was totally impressed.   Not only was the cinematography excellent, and the technological usage terrific, but the storyline was quite impressively original, something that you do not see all that much out of Hollywood these days.   I haven't looked into it yet, but I would like to find out if it came from a book already written, or if it was on its own a screenplay.   Regardless, the writer who thought of such an idea is amazing.   Oh how I wish I could think so differently...

So, all my friends who raved about it incessantly, you were 100% right!

Do you talk about your friends in a negative light behind their back? How often?

Submitted by hollyw1se 


I'd love to automatically say, "Absolutely not! Never would I do that!"  But the truth is that if something is bothering me about someone I know then the easiest way for me to deal with it is through discussion with another friend or friends.

Optimally I do not believe that anyone should talk negatively about anyone without giving them the opportunity to defend themselves, but sometimes you get to the point where you are not 100% sure what to do about the situation.  Well, I do anyway.  It's a horrible position to be in, where someone you love or care about is doing something that you have difficulty accepting, and if all was perfect there should be no problem with telling them that, but we are human beings and imperfect.

So, in answer to this question, I'm a hypocrite, because I do do this even though I don't believe in it.  Horribly, sometimes I sicken myself when I might do it for more petty reasons, such as gossip, or fitting in with the other person in the discussion.  These are some of the lowest times.

I just found this excellent, more adult, Writer's Block community at wb_unplugged and I joined it!   From what I've read so far, it isn't all that hairy, but I'm letting my readers know to prepare themselves for some upcoming dissertations that may have a possibility of curling their toes...

I have taken ownership of a new phone and a Nintendo Wii system in the last week, all part of a new plan I went onto from my phone company.   I'm not a mobile phone person, but today I found out that I can access my email, Yahoo messenger, and the internet through my phone!   Pretty amazing I reckon.   Also has a camera, and takes video, and is an mp3 player.

Shit, maybe I'll have to get rid of this excitement before I become a "mobile phone person."

Can't wait to work out how it will make my bed for me in the morning...

My mother always says that God must have some great purpose in mind for me, because (s)He (my mother would never go with 'she' but I'm more open-minded) has prevented me from dying a few times. Apparently as a little baby I nearly crawled out a second-story window of a building when a family friend picked me up and stopped me. A beautiful woman, I am still friends with her to this very day, forty-odd years later. As a pre-teen child while holidaying in Tasmania, we were swimming in a creek that had a fast current out further. My father told us not to go there as it was too fast, and of course I didn't listen. I remember trying to hold rocks below me and they just giving way and pulling up as I grasped them to get some stability. Eventually one of the young men who were frolicking about in the current earlier (that made me want to swim out there) grabbed a hold of me and pulled me to the shore. I think the river lowered its level that day as I swallowed so much of it. In my twenties I took up skydiving and would work all week to go to the drop-zone on the weekend and spend my pay buying one-way tickets to height. One day, while doing a demonstration jump for students (of which one was my brother), I lost consiousness shorty after pulling my parachute. I was heading downwind at the time and the estimates are that I hit the ground limp with a forward speed of 60-70 km per hour. I do not remember anything of the next few days, but I survived that one too. Finally...near-death? Maybe not quite as close as others, but while visiting, and staying with the family of an online friend in Beaumont, Texas in 2000, her husband (who, incidentally, had had his wife, my friend, sleeping on the sofa for the previous 18 months or so) got it into his head that I was "doing" his wife and we were having a grand old time. It wasn't so (though I wish it was), but he was motivated enough to get his gun out before his wife told him to stop being stupid and not make a mistake. Needless to say, she and her son dropped me at the local bus station at 2am the next morning to catch the 3.15 bus out of Beaumont... So, does God really have some special purpose for me in mind, or have I just been insanely lucky? I do not know either way, but it will never stop me from doing my best to always live life.

<lj-template name="qotd" id="1687" lang="en_LJ" />

When a band you have liked since the early days makes it big, one should be happy for them and all the hard work they've put in, and also that more people have started to recognise how good they are.   The main problem for me is that I feel like my interest in them is kind of devalued if everyone else now likes them also, like my precious little secret now has to be shared with so many more people.

This has happened with a few bands/artists I've known of in my younger years.   I wish I could just be happy for them without the empty feeling of selfishness that overcomes me...

Well, I tried to take some photos of Tom on friday, and as the good little pup that he is, he wasn't very co-operative. But of the three photos I took, this is the best. And that is a big bowl that is upside-down next to him, so it may deceive you as to hi actual size... but here he is:

BIG NEWS UPDATE:

On Saturday I entered a committed relationship with a 4-month-old Rottweiler pup!

I've loved Rotties ever since spending time with my cousin in the States in 2000, as he had three of them!   I've wanted one ever since.   And now the lovely Tom and I are sharing each other's lives indefinitely.

Tom was named after two of my 'heroes' (not that I really have heroes, but these are people I honour greatly), singer/songwriter extraordinaire Tom Waits, and legendary cricketer and primary contributor to the 'invention' of Australian Rules football Tom Wills (google them if you do not know).   

Yesterday I was considering what his full name would be, and I laughingly came up with Tom Will Wait (definitely something this little energetic puppy does not much of at the moment).

No photos as yet, but I hope to take some real soon, otherwise he will be a lot bigger.

Hi everyone. My head and arse are both very sore from kicking and slapping myself about not posting more often here. Yeah yeah, I know, you've heard it all before... I've found a spare ten minutes or so to jot down an update on what is happening. Currently I am the holder of four (yes 4!) casual jobs, and my juggling skills are rapidly improving with each passing day. Since March or April I've been working one or two days a week at a piggery just 40km out of town. It is dirty work, but I actually like to get working and be able to lose my mind from everything else happening. I'm also at the Discovery Science and Technology Centre in Bendigo, which is also a lot of fun, though I do not get as much work as I'd like to there. Another role is as an underground tour guide at the Central Deborah tourist gold mine in the centre of town. This is probably my favourite at the moment, and where I'm getting the most work currently, however I couldn't solely survive on it alone, as it is not enough. And lastly, I begin a new job this Saturday, working as a carer for an intellectually disabled man through an organisation called Loddon Mallee Housing Services. It's been a while since I've done work like this, but the opportunity arose and was too good to pass up. And for a start it will only be Saturday work, so it will not get in the way of other jobs much. I truly hope you are all well - I was motivated to post this because I was cleaning out my email inbox when I came across a couple of LJ friends' emails to me, and slapped myself up the head again! Keep happy. Your eternally unreliable, and regularly absent Brendan.

BUSY!

I'm wondering if I've posted a post in the last year or so where I haven't mentioned how busy I've been.   I feel fortunate though, as my life is a stimulating one that is full, and sometimes even rewarding.

The latest excitement in my life has been to do with music, which is always wonderful when it affects my life.


Last weekend in Bendigo was the Gorgeous Voices Festival and was amazing.   By the time Sunday night came around I was physically exhausted!   And that is no exaggeration!

Friday night began with an afternoon/evening showcase/welcome of artists who would be around for the weekend, which was a great little taste that went for about two-and-a-bit hours.   After that I moseyed on up to the grandstand at the local footy ground, the home of the Bendigo Folk Club, to see a show by one of my favourite songwriters, Kavisha Mazzella.   Before Kavisha was a family band from a town just down the road from Bendigo.   I'd never heard them, but their name is The Rainmakers, and they were a wonderful surprise, that I got to spend an entertaining time listening to.

Saturday morning saw my usual start to the weekend of Bendigo Laughter Club, of which I am a facilitator.    This had nothing to do with the festival, but is always a wonderful part of my weekend.   From there I went to a couple of hours of choir practice, for my first experience in a choir (apart from as a youngster at church) at the end of the weekend.   Saturday in Bendigo was busy with things that weren't just to do with the festival, and there was a children's carnival in the main park, where I was working between 12 and 4, in a tent set up by one of my workplaces, the Discovery Science and Technology Centre.   Our tent was called "The Grossology Tent" and we spent the afternoon making fake scabs on kids' bodies, slimy snot that they could take home and play with, and my main job was teaching the kids about what is in poo and then making some fake poo out of a host of yummy ingrdients so that they could EAT IT!   A few kids (and parents) weren't interested in the poo, but I had to go to the supermarket at one stage to get extra supplies!   Yummy poo...    Between three and seven there was an open mike at the grandstand, and I had my guitar in the car and went on up and heard some great music, as well as played three songs, which all went well.   Quick drive home for dinner and then out to a premiere of a "folk-rock-opera" that was written by a local.   The music was more beautiful than I can describe, but it finished earlier than I expected, at about 9:15pm.   Back over to the grandstand to hear someone I'd never heard of before named Jo Jo Smith.   At the end of the night my jaw was sore due to its constnt state of being gawkingly hanging open.   An older woman, Jo Jo played a nylon-string guitar like a maestro, and sung with a gusto and passion that made me totally envious.   And her voice was beautiful.   Check her website at the link...there're some good songs you can hear.

Sunday morning was another two hours of choir practice.   I could've done some workshops before the finale concert but I needed some lunch and wanted to organise some 'cheat notes' for songs I didn't know by heart.   The finale was at the Catholic Sacred Heart Cathedral, a massive behemoth of intricate architecture that, even though it was a fine day, was pretty chily inside of.   I'd battled most of the weekend with a runny-nosed cold, and after we finished singing and I sat down to watch the end of the concert, I couldn't stop shivering.   Reluctantly, I left when the last act started, because I was feeling the agony.   I'm sure it was also from exhaustion too.   When I got back to my car, parked facing the lowering afternoon sun, it was so heated inside that I simply put some music on (the CD of Jo Jo I'd bought the night before) and put the seat back to recover from my cold.   It was about 4.20pm then and when I opened my eyes again it was 5.30, so maybe I was tired...

What a beautiful joy-giving weekend with a host of marvellous, talented, and personally edifying people to share time with.   I encourage you to have a look at all of the links I've put in this post, as you may just find some great additions to your life.

Much love to you all.

I've actually broken mirrors purposely in the past for use in my art, and if I see an upright ladder with easy access to walk under I will often take that route as a preference to "avoiding" bad luck.    I think we all have superstitions, be they major or minor, large or small, but perhaps I'm one of these people who doesn't like to be tied down by "rules" and especially ones that don't make any sense.

I still have my own superstitions though, mainly to do with my wife:   I think it is bad luck to ever say yes to her when she asks me if her bum looks big in whatever she's wearing, or to be caught checking out another girl by her.   So you see, none of us are immune to superstitions...

I've been reading a book lately, and it has some quite amazing quotes in it at times, among a great story.   I'm only just over 12o pages in, and it is 900+ pages long, but I've spoken to three people who've read it and they've all told me it will be a page-turner that can't be put down.   This bit I read tonight really struck me...

"One of the reasons why we crave love, and seek it so desperately, is that love is the only cure for loneliness, and shame, and sorrow. But some feelings sink so deep into the heart that only loneliness can help you find them again. Some truths about yourself are so painful that only shame can help you live with them. And some things are just so sad that only your soul can do the crying for you."
- Gregory David Roberts, 'Shantaram'

I'm a fraction behind in posting this, but as of Monday 27th July, I have lost 16 kgs in the last 12 weeks!   American friends, that is 35 pounds!   And how happy I am...

By the way, that just undoes the hell of a sabotage I did on myself in the previous 3 months when I put on about 32 pounds as a response to emotional trauma and physical injury.   But all the same, I feel great, and my clothes are fitting me nicer at the moment.

Just wanted to share something positive with everyone...and I'm proud of myself too.



How about this: I challenge anyone who reads this entry to post a reply to it with something positive in it also.   From your life, and it can be about anything you like (I'm sure we'll get some creative ones here), but it needs to be positive.   It's often very difficult for prople to say anything positive these days, so please, give it a go for me...

"If there is someone on your friends list you would like to take, strip naked with, let them tie you to a bed post, have them lick you until you scream, then fuck until both of you are senseless and unable to fuck anymore, then wait about five minutes and do it all over again, post this exact sentence in your journal."

I wanna make an entry, but don't really have much of interest to say.

I'm still running.

I'm still writing.

Not much else happening...

Yes, am back from my vacation now, and just getting around to posting about the last five-or-so days because I got my photos sorted out.

A HUGE thanks to one of my friends, long-time friend Leslie, who, after my post about my limitations on Flickr, gifted me a year's pro account, so I was able to put them all there.   So you can now go to http://www.flickr.com/photos/brendanooo/ to see all the pics I took while in the north, and I've put them in separate folders so you know where they were.

I discovered while doing it that at least one of the days I didn't reset my camera's date and time, so it is all stuffed, with the date showing 1999 or something, but I can assure you that they were taken during the holiday.

My last post mentioned how beautiful Edith Falls was, and this pic was taken from a lookout as I hiked around the Falls loop circuit.   These were the top two pools, of which you couldn't safely get to the bottom one in the picture, but the main swimming area was the next pool down, not in the picture, which was much bigger.   Due to time constraints I didn't get to swim here, but the top pool was my favourite.

And this was taken while we were in Kakadu National Park for the last three days of our trip.   We saw many things there, and I hiked a lot, but this was at one of two sites we visited that had a bevy of aboriginal rock art (again, look at my Flickr), Anbangbang being where this was at.   Due to the extra detail in this image, it was probably painted in the last 400-800 years, but we saw lots of other images that could date thousands of years old.

I've been run-walking (Ralking, I call it) for the last couple of months now.   Sometimes I just walk, but for the last five or six weeks I've been using the streetpoles to regulate my running pattern.   I started by running 2 poles length and then walking 2.   Then dropped the walking back to one.   And eventually gradually increased the running up to 7.   Seven poles running for one walking was pretty good, but my goal was to run my 5 km circuit non-stop eventually.

Whilst away on holiday for the last two weeks, primarily due to lots of unmade roads that wouldn't be good for twisting ankles and the like, I didn't run, but I hiked daily.

After getting back I got back into it easy, doing a 3-1 pattern on Saturday.   Today I awoke at 5.40, as is my usual choice, and decided I'd run as long as I could.

AND TODAY WAS THE FIRST DAY I RAN THE 5 KM NON-STOP!!!

Surprisingly it wasn't that tough, probably due to the conditioning I've been building up, but the last 500 or 600 metres was run on willpower as my legs started to tire.  I'd never counted all the poles before today, and now I know that the poles I count total 87.   Eighty-seven poles in about 40 minutes - not lightning speed, but stamina was the first goal, and while I don't know exactly, I'm sure I'm still weighing over 110 kg (about 242 pound), so that's not too bad.

So now I start to run faster, then further, and eventually I will reach my goal to run a marathon!

Hi everyone.

Yesterday we travelled from Berry Springs to Katherine, and it was a great drive, the absolute highlight being a visit to Edith Falls (google it and tell me what you think).

We're only in Katherine for one night, and today we are doing a Katherine Gorge river cruise before driving back up to Kakadu National Park.   While there internet access will be very little if any at all.   We'll be home on Friday, so I'll post anything then that I wish to, including more photos.

Speaking of photos, as I'm not a pro member at Flickr, I ran out of space for photos, so have reverted to my old Photobucket.com account.   I'm not sure how you can go about it, but if you go to photobucket and do a search for brendanobrien (all one word) hopefully it will show you my pages and you can find the latest photos.   Otherwise you'll just have to wait until I get home and update.   Sorry, but it can't be helped.

until next time...

G'day everyone from up in the tropics of northern Australia!   And the highlights just keep on coming...

I've owned a didjeridu for many years now, but rarely play it.   I can make good sound but cannot circular breathe, and living in a family, etc, means you often do not have opportunities to play.   Since we've been here there are didjeridus everywhere and I've been playing daily.   Last week a father and son visited our holiday park to talk about playing and making didjeridus.   To cut a long story short, I arranged to visit them in Darwin, and on Thursday myself and my youngest son got to make our own didjeridus!   It was very exciting, and I love it.   Hopefully now I'll become a better player and be more motivated to practice...

Yesterday I visited the Territory Wildlife Park again, this time for a Twilight Tour, from 6pm until about 9pm.   I actually got there around 4 in the afternoon and thought I'd have a look around and maybe a bit of a relax.   Truly, the place is very beautiful.

I decided to go and sit out by Goose Lagoon in the late afternoon and perhaps get some nice pics, or even just enjoy the afternoon symphony of the bird life around the lagoon.   Sitting quietly reading my book, and looking up every so often, I got a surprise to see three rather sizeable animals wading in the water on the other side of the lagoon.   My camera isn't great, but I took some shots, although I wasn't sure what they were.   They looked more stocky than deer, and I thought they may be gnu, but I don't think we have gnu in Oz, so what would they be doing here???   I spoke with a guide later and he told me they had 3 or 4 Samba deer in the park, which are Northern Territory imports from SE Asia.   He said they were quite shy and nobody ever saw them much, so that was a real thrill for for me!

When the Twilight Tour started it was very special as there was a family of three (mum and two kids) and me!   Just four of us!   There were too many highlights to mention them all, but a couple were:

- seeing  a female Black Wallaby, which are very rare in that they only live in one small part of the Northern Territory and nowhere else on earth.   They only had one of them at the park and were hoping to get a male at some stage and try to start a breeding program.

- getting to hold a carpet python.   I love snakes even though I've never owned one, and this one was a beauty.   Named Stanley, they thought it was a male, but recently found out it was female.   Because it has been called Stanley always I do not think they'll change it, so I christened her Stanleigh, trying to put a bit of femininity into her name.

I've added more photos, so feel free to go look at http://www.flickr.com/photos/brendanooo/ and feel free to comment if you are so inspired.

Hi all. Life up here at the top of Australia is going pretty good right now. We've been looking around and exploring plenty of places with many highlights.

Yesterday we spent the day looking around the Litchfield National Park, which was wonderful for me, as my love of nature and hiking and such is quite all-encompassing of myself. Think about this: at the top end of Australia there is constant public announcement and warning signs about the presence of crocodiles in waterways. Indeed, nobody (except idiots and tourists who don't know better) swim at the beaches, because there are freshwater and saltwater crocodiles all around. Yesterday at Litchfield we visited two waterfalls and a set of rockholes that anybody could swim at. I don't know why, but there are no crocs around (actually, one of the falls - Wangi Falls - had a sign saying there were freshwater crocs local that were only dangerous if annoyed, but otherwise they fed on insects and plant life), and the water was crystal clear. No jokes, you could see right to the bottom of any areas that were 6 foot or so deep! And my favourite was Florence falls, where you could sit in the water and all around you were beautiful black fish swimming, some big enough to be a meal for two people if they were edible and you could catch them (I do not know if either is applicable or allowed), and with my goggles on it was amazing to swim amongst them.

We also spent a day at the Territory Wildlife Park, which was a full day's experience and was wonderfully amazing. They had all sorts of different animals there, as well as different habitats and mini-forests to walk through. I may even go back there again before we leave...

  

These two places have been my highlights, but there've been so many so far that it is too difficult to pick an absolute. Crocosaurus Cove was another ripper. And, not at Crocosaurus Cove, but we got to buy croc fillets to cook and I ate croc meat for the first time ever! It's a white meat and tastes very much like pork. Very nice, and no fat to speak of.

If you'd like to peruse through any of my other photos, I'm uploading them to my Flickr site at http://www.flickr.com/photos/brendanooo and there'll be more to come!

Until next time, stay happy!

OK, it's the first of July here now, so I'll put out my first blog prompt of the month. Someone suggested posting one a week, and that may well be a good idea, but I may not even get to doing that! Anyway, I'll try to do at least four for the month, and this one may take a few days anyway.

The idea is to use the prompt to post something on your own livejournal blog, or any other you may have that you wish to. So that others might see what you have done, I'd appreciate it if you wouldn't mind posting in a comment here a link to your blog page where your response to the prompt is.

First prompt:

COLLECT SHADOWS!

This means take photographs of shadows that are interesting, appeal to you, might be of yourself, buildings, other structures, animals etc, etc, etc. Let your mind go and the ideas may flow!

Hello ladies and germs.

this will be quick because the internet access we have here is good, but a little expensive.   At the top end of Australia here, it is quite tropical, with temperatures sitting around 32 degrees centigrade (check the conversion, American friends) during the day, and perhaps getting down to 23-25 degrees at night.   We left Victoria (on the southern coast of the mainland) on Thursday night and it was between 6 and 8 degrees centigrade, and we were really cold, so this is the total other end of the scale.

I'm sorry if I'm gonna disappoint anyone, but the month of blog prompts won't be happening as I think I'll find it too difficult to keep up with.   Maybe next month?   We'll wait and see.

I've taken a number of photos so far, and if I can work out an easy way to upload them to flickr, you might get to see them before we come home, otherwise, everyone will just have to wait.

Hope everyone is well and happy...

...is paved with good intentions, right?

Since posting about my monthly prompts, and professing to intend to pre-make a list before the month to take off the pressure...well...guess what?   I've got the original two things I wrote and that is all.

:O(

We leave for our holiday in about 3.5 days, and I've found out that the last 4 days of our holiday we will be in Kakadu National Park (look it up, it is beautiful) and the only internet access will be one computer in the resident-park manager's office, and it is dial-up.   So I'm kind of resigned to have no contact, or very little then.

I'll try to add to the list today again, but we'll see how it all goes...

Hope you are all wonderful!

Hmmm...it's been a busy week, but I reckon the best thing was that I have officially moved from going for a walk in the morning to going for a run.   I've always hated running, found it boring, and being a lifetime overweight person...well, it has always been major hard work.   A few years ago a person I met told me he was a running addict, and when I showed him around town (walking), whenever we saw an expanse of grass (like the football ground, or the main gardens in town) he would audibly say something like, "Oh man, I just want to run!"   We talked about it and he told me that if I started he thought that it would be difficult to not run when I was out.   And I reckon he could be right, because on Thursday I wanted a day off (it's still not easy, but getting easier) and was just gonna walk, but it only took a block before I was running!

So I'm feeling healthy and fit and am aiming to look a lot different by September!

A big answer for such a little question, but you guys know me...talk underwater and all...

While looking at the prompts I mentioned yesterday, a few of them took my interest, and one in particular was to take stock of everything I consumed in one day.   While it isn't really fair right now, as I am on an eating plan, I thought it would be particularly interesting to itemise everything.   No junk food for me now, but what would you have on it if you took stock of one day's consumption?

My list:

87 grams strawberries
14 grams raspberries
1 apple
1 mandarine
280 grams low-fat yoghurt
85 grams extra-light tasty cheese
199 grams ham
126 grams mushrooms
65 grams green capsicum
34 grams red capsicum
29 grams brocolli
35 grams zucchini
24 grams asparagus
30 grams carrot
42 grams gherkin
5 almonds
3 grape tomatoes
4 stuffed olives
3 water crackers
1 multi-vitamin capsule
2 tablespoons pumpkin seeds (pepitas)
1 tablespoon flaxseed oil
1 tablespoon extra-virgin olive oil
1 tablespoon sunflower seeds
2 teaspoons tahini
sprinkle of cumin
sprinkle of oregano
sprinkle of turmeric
3.525 litres of water

if you do it, can you at least please post a comment with the link to your LJ so me and others can look at it?

I've been spending some time looking around at creative websites and blogs and the like AND BEEN GETTING VERY INSPIRED!   A lady who is very talented had a month of blog prompts on her site for the month of March.   They were all very interesting - some simple, some a bit more work, but it seemed like they could be a lot of fun.

So, I have a few of questions to whomever may be reading this (and I'm not feeling sorry for myself, it's just that since I get here so infrequently, I can't expect to have the same amount of readers as I once did):

1.   Who visits their LJ daily (or very regularly), and also posts regularly?

2.   Who would like to have a few challenges thrown at them for a month, that they can post on their blogs?

3.   Do most people have access to or own a digital camera?  I'll probably do a few photo prompts, and photos on your blog are a good way to show what you've done, even if they aren't photo prompts.

I'm thinking the month of July might be a good one, although I will be on holiday until the 8th (and will be interstate), but I'm planning on taking my laptop with me, and will hopefully find somewhere to get online regularly.   Optimally every day would be a good way to do this, but I think it will probably just be posted as "prompt #1", "prompt #2", etc, whenever I can.

It's just an idea, but I thought I'd like to put it out there, and it will be more fun if I can share it with others and we can see what we are doing.   And I'll try to make them varied, with arty, photo-y, writing, talking, listening, reflecting prompts.   And any others I can think of.

Please comment so I can get a feel of how you feel.

He couldn’t remember much of the accident. He remembered it had been a long day. Then he remembered the pain, and the car feeling like it was sideways. He found it weird that it was night, as he’d been driving in the afternoon. He must’ve dozed off.

The ambos told him he was in a deep crevasse, and it was still daylight. Their voices sounded laboured, as if they were working hard, or had worked hard already. Or maybe it was both. His eyesight must be affected, they told him, but he should be happy he was still breathing, as they hadn’t expected to find life.

After the metal-tearing sounds stopped he felt a harness put under his arms. It was soft, and could’ve been lamb’s wool, but that was never this soft. A voice called out that they were ready to go. For a couple of seconds there was a grinding sound before he felt a soft jolt pulling at the front of the harness, dragging him upwards.

Then the pain. It had dulled while the men had worked, and now it shot through his entire body like never before…

Hi all!

Things are still busy but I'm trying to make the effort to get in here at least once a week if I can.   I hope everyone is well and happy.

I know that some of my friends here are very much into reading and writing, so I want to let you know about a couple of sites I've been hanging out at lately.

One that I recently mentioned to you was http://www.100words.com/ for which I'm currently completing the June batch.

Here's one of my latest:

$20 was never going to be enough for what Simon had planned for his first date with Melissa.   He’d begged his mother for some more money, pleading that he’d been asking Melissa out for months.   His mum was unmoving in her stance that he got weekly pocket money and always spent it quickly on things that were just for his entertainment, regardless of how many times he was told he should save some.   When she asked what he had planned, and he told her dinner and a movie, she simply remarked, “Maybe she’d like a Big Mac and playing Nintendo…”

And a site that a contact from there just told me about, and I'm very excited about, is http://ficly.com and I think that many of you might like to join this one (come on, it is lots of fun).   The link to my bio page is this: http://ficly.com/authors/brendano

I hope to see some of you there (please pretty please grovel grovel grovel)...

I know it has been a long time since I last posted here, but I didn't think it was that long!

Much has been happening (as I always seem to type) on many different levels, not the least of which has been relational and marital trauma.   My marriage is still together and I'm happy about that, and time will see if things progress upwards or downwards in the future.   Time's good like that...

This year I've been trying to re-embrace my artistic side, which got a little neglected for quite some time there, and rediscover my happiness.   It's an ongoing journey, which is cruising at the moment.   I perticularly wanted to start writing again, which I haven't done for a long time.   Finding some acquaintances of mine also were interested in it, I began to imagine and formulate a writing group.   It still hasn't formally started yet, but my mind has been working overtime developing prompts, projects, and the like.   This has been stimulating and uplifting for me, even though I still haven't been writing much.

And recently I rediscovered the 100 Words website.   Remember almost a year and a half ago when I'd occasionally post my 100-word creations?   Well, I'm back at them.   And enjoying it too.   Today's is below, with thanks to my friend Gary for inspiration for the topic.

Once upon a time, when fairytales held great importance, there was a man whose job it was to ensure that all children’s stories began with the words “Once upon a time.” 

This wasn’t as simple as just tacking them before a story.   Not all opening sentences can simply have that prenunciation placed before and still make sense.   Sometimes it placed this man in the position of editor, needing to change and manipulate the opening sentence in the correct way.  

And when he, as all writers sometimes face, fell victim to ‘writer’s block,’ well, it was hell.   Imagine: “Once upon a time…aaarrgghhh!”

Would you look at that!   It's exactly one month today since I last posted.   Isn't that typical pathetic the way things sometimes get...no rest for the wicked, eh.

And while we are on the cliches, if only the good die young and there is no rest for the wicked, I'm destined to be busy busy busy for a long long time!

I'm still liking my job, although I really do have no life on the days that I work.   A fourteen-hour day means you have time to eat and maybe watch a movie when you get home before hitting the sack to go back again the next morning.   But you look forward to your days off, you surely do.   The only problem there is that you plan things to do while you are off, and that just makes the time fly by all that much more quickly.   Hahaha...am I complaining enough???

This last few days was pretty magical for me though, as one of my favourite bands, Weddings Parties Anything, just finished their 10-year reunion tour.   The end of the tour is officially in London, England, with one show at an old haunt of theirs next weekend, but the true tour end was in their hometown (and my hometown) of Melbourne, where they broke a long-standing record at the venue by having 5 straight sold out shows!

And I got to see two of them!

My actual highlight of the shows was the final show, a Sunday "matinee" show, which was organised primarily in recognition that they have such a loyal fan base, many of who are much more advanced in years now than they were during the 14 or so years the band played in their heydays.   The matinee show was a "family friendly" gig, with anyone bringing children under twelve being able to bring them in for free.   It was an impressive sight to see babies and young children throughout the pub being rocked and bounced around to the music with their parents.   A lovely lovely event.

And the biggest highlight for me:   A band I used to sell merchandise for, Overnight Jones, who ceased playing around the same time the "Weddoes" did (and who owe a lot of their success to WPA for many years of supports and the like), actually made a reunion at the matinee, playing for over an hour after Weddings Parties Anything finished!   No packed house for this bit, with many of the kids needing to be tucked into bed after a long day, but quite a few die-hard fans stuck around to enjoy a fantastic event at the end of an already fantastic event!   It culminated with the band playing one of their traditional finishing songs over the years, the Bob Dylan cover "The Mighty Quinn", and being joined on stage by all of WPA as well as the roadies, merchandisers, and a few others closely connected with the band.

What a day, what a day...music is something that there is nothing else like in the whole world.

...just the same as always, it has been a long time between drinks, indeed it has.

Tonight, on my second-last night off before getting back to work for another 9 or 10 straight 12-hour days, I watched a wonderful movie that I'd never even heard of before.   Given to me by a friend of mine, it is called The Man From Earth.   After going to imdb.com I saw it was made last year and actually has quite a high rating, meaning people who can bother putting a vote in think well of it.

No spoilers, but it is about a man who has apparently been living for 14,000 (yes fourteen thousand) years, who decides to share it with some good and learned friends.   I was engrossed from the start of the movie right through until the end.   This was a really good way to spend some 90-or-so minutes tonight.





p.s.   to all of my mates on here, I'm sincerely apologetic for not keeping up with your LJs and/or posting comments, as I know you know I enjoy doing.   life really is getting in the way in recent times...

I know I have a lot of "readers" on my flist.   Has anyone here read the Mitch Albom book For One More Day?   I just finished reading it this morning and I honestly think it may have instigated changes in my life.   

If you have read it, did you love it as much as I did, and did it affect you greatly?   If you haven't read it I honestly believe you should.   I kind of think everybody should.   I'm going to offer it to my boys to read and, even though I think they'll probably reject it because it isn't about aliens, witches, or elves, I want to discuss it with them when they have finished it.

And when my wife and kids are finished with it, I'll find someone else to pass it on to.

Nothing makes a 12-hour night shift more ultimately bearable than cous-cous and chickpea salad.

YUM!


Well, maybe sex for afters would make it more bearable, but that's never going to happen here, so I'll love and enjoy the salads!

I'm just a little interested (okay, more than just a little):

What do you do to pick yourself up when you get in a funk, the sads, depression, a case of the blues, or whatever else you might refer to it as?

I could do with some suggestions right now...

Well, isn't this one a tough one...

PRACTICAL: toothpaste and toothbrush set

FRIVOLOUS: $20 worth of chocolate!

MY CHOICE: a set of guitar strings


I think if I did this one every day for a year I'd probably think of different things for all three categories.
eco-friendly tip: re-use old newspapers and magazines by cutting out the letters and making a note for somebody special...especially asking for money.

Yowza!   Our writer's block prompter is on a bit of an art spin lately, eh...

This is far from easy to answer for me, as I have been so fully indulgent in art in recent years, and therefore exposed to so much, I have a hard time stipulating who would be an outright favourite.

Historically, from when I was a young boy, my favourite artist was an Australian impressionist from the Heidelberg school, named FredericK McCubbin.   He painted many fine paintings to do with the Australian bush, and some are quite famous and renowned, many being typical fodder for placement in banks and other conservative people places.   My favourite painting by McCubbin is called Down On His Luck, portraying an old swaggy sitting by a smoking fire.



I found this online, and I don't really remember it with this colour in it, I do believe it was 'browner', but perhaps that is only the printed image I have seen of it, as I've never seen the original.

There are many others I love as well, but attempting to list them would be a futile exercise.

The same goes for musical artists.   As far as art goes, I think music is my most beloved realm, but the list of favoured artists would be as long as my arm I think, and that would be even if the font were only 10pt.   Hahaha.

Art.   One of the most important things in the world.   For both the protrayer and the appreciator.

Working 12-hour shifts is not necessarily an easy task.

Working 12-hour night  shifts can have its challenges also, even though I personally prefer night shift.

But on nights like tonight it is sometimes a joy.

I was walking down to the workshop from my office, as the fitter was servicing my work vehicle, and as I walked along in the dark night, guided by the lights from the office block and the lights from the mine area (where I was headed), I saw that the sky was as clear as clear could be.   And the stars were so so bright.   And as I looked up, at about 3.45am, right in the middle of the sky above me, big and beautiful as I'd never seen it before, was the constellation of The Southern Cross, which also adorns our national flag.   It was so beautiful and so perfect that I instantly forgot about my fatigue as I was just thankful for this unexpected blessing.

Have any of you ever had a similar experience?   An unexpected blessing, perhaps when you least expected it?

Hmmm...anything artistic...not that hard really.

I've always wanted to plant a forest, to grow a forest, and have thought that if everything was perfect I would plant it in a shape, as a statement.   And it would be able to be seen easily from above, and would be something very very special.

Yes, a forest in the shape of a heart, or a peace symbol, or a hand, or perhaps an orb, representative of the earth.

What was the best invention prior to sliced bread?

And, for that matter, when, where, and who is credited with the "invention" of sliced bread, as opposed to the regular, unsliced variety?

<lj-template name="qotd" id="279"></lj-template>Ummm...I've lost count of the number of times I've made a fool of myself!   And the only way they could've been improved upon was to not do them in the first place.   Hehehe...somehow I don't think I'm alone on this one...

Okay, just 2 days to go until my first complete monthly batch is achieved!   How exciting.   Well, it is for me, anyway...

Here's my latest installment:


----------------------------------------

Shh, Shhhh, I love this song...

You love this song? Really? But this so-

I said shush! Let me listen to it!

But this song is about someone getting shitfaced drunk and beating up on their girlfriend...

It is not!

It is so! You love this song and you haven't listened to the words properly? But you're singing along with it...

Well...I just like the sound of it, ok?

(rolling eyes) Oh right, and I'm sure Martin Bryant liked the feel of a gun in his hand...

What? Who the hell is Martin Bryant???

Argghhh...words mean nothing anymore!

Sometimes I do not get to see a movie for what seems like forever, and sometimes in a short period of time I seem to make up for lost time in a big way.   In the last week-and-a-bit I have seen 4 movies, all fairly high quality, and thought I'd share my impressions.   If anyone else has seen them or wants to share, feel free!

-------------------------------------------------------------------
The most recent one I watched, was probably the oldest of the lot, from last year, Gone Baby Gone.



Considering I didn't know much about this one before watching it, I was majorly impressed by this fairly bluntly-hitting real-life movie.   As always, I don't want to spoil anything with details you don't need me to say, but the twists in this one, particularly in the latter stages, as well as the ethical and social challenges faced by the main character make it well worth a watch.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Before Gone Baby Gone (yes I watched two in a row, waking early and not being able to get back to sleep, so I figured, "Why not?") I watched the new Johnny Depp movie, Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street.



I wasn't really that interested in this one, but it was very well made indeed.   A little unreal in its storyline, and an amazing surprise that it was a musical (I hope that doesn't spoil it for anyone), I ended up enjoying it, even though I wouldn't necessarily go and tell people it is one not to miss.   Worthwhile to watch, and maybe it might've been better had I seen it on the big screen.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
A couple of days earlier my wife and I watched Juno, another movie I had seen advertised but hadn't grabbed my interest previously.



The best of the four in my opiion, this was a wonderful movie about a girl of 16 who falls pregnant, chooses to offer the child up to a couple who'd like a baby, and all of the little intricacies that go along with that storyline.   A very very enjoyable movie with a soundtrack that absolutely ROCKS!   The whole time I was watching the movie I was thinking what a great soundtrack it was, and before the movie had even finished I was looking for the soundtrack online.   Watch this one if you get a chance.   I'm even thinking of going to a cinema to see it now.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
And finally, the first of this lot was the Cohen Brothers' latest, No Country For Old Men.



This one is a bit more "alternative" than the others (although Sweeney Todd is pretty alternative too!), without a nice rounded-off ending.   Very well shot, and with reviews that simply made me want to see it, I was mildly disappointed.   An extremely good movie, maybe I just expected more from all the reviews I'd heard.   If you like a nicely "full" story with a happy ending, don't worry about this one.   My wife hated it.   She definitely prefers a more neatly-formatted movie.

It is with regret that I announce, only 3 portraits in to the 52 planned for this year, that the project is no more.

The reason for this is that my wife feels as though I have minimised the importance of my family in my life by not including her or either of my two sons in the first three weeks. As an artist, the last thing I wanted was for my project to come across as a family photo album, and I had planned to include all three of them at some stage in the process, but I obviously made the wrong choice by not making them weeks 2-4 (there is sarcasm in that statement in case you couldn't read it).

Music takes a far higher place in my life than just about anything, to the extent that I'm currently deciding on my first tattoo ever to reflect that. Anyone who has had any "musical" interraction with me knows that my preference is for lyrical music, or "storytelling" songs. Over the years, having listened to many singer-songwriters plying their craft, often extremely beautifully, via tunes about women (or men) other than their partners, I often wondered if their spouses ever had issues. Nick Cave for example, is somewhat "notorious" for this, but surely his songwriting and musical talent in expressing his art would "negate" (bad word, but I cannot grasp the right one at the moment) any insecure feelings his partner may have. I mean, it is what he does as his passion. And to be fair, that should read passion, passion, or PASSION in order to place correct emphasis on it.

Some artists, writers, musicians discipline themselves so rigorously to nurture, develop, and extend their passion, spending a certain amount of hours each day just for what they are passionate about. In a perfect world, that would be what any people with artistic inclinations would be able to do. However, some of us have to work and lead "outside" lives as well, disabling the possibility of a Utopian existence in our artistic lives.

The reason for the above paragraph's observation is that without the above discipline, any other artistically-leaning persons often need to rely on "inspiration", and to be quite blunt about it, this FUCKING SUCKS (note the appropriate emphasis on that to portray how important I mean it), because one so wants to keep creating and cannot do it because everything else gets in the way.

So I set projects to enable me to have parameters to aim for so that my artistic muse will not feel neglected, as it has for the last year or so. And I do not really need other shit that I cannot see coming getting in the way of it.

I know I think differently from many people on many issues, but am I alone in thinking that the woman I profess my love for daily (appropriate emphasis again), that I've been married to for 5 years, who's two sons I have taken on as my own (with it's own major set of complications not going to be mentioned here), is letting her insecurities get in the way where they shouldn't???

Just to put it on the record, I can understand how she may feel this way, but I do not give it credence because if it were a bucket it wouldn't have a bottom and therefore would not hold a drop of water. Am I being heartless, uncaring, irresponsible? Or give me any other word that comes to your mind (from the sound of that last sentence, "arrogant" may well fit in there too, but I think it is just anger at the moment), because I'll value feedback on this one, and welcome you to be as brutal as you feel you need to be, because if I am seriously missing something here, maybe I need to know about it.

Regardless, this project has provided more grief than I foresaw, so it is still going to die it's premature death. Now I feel I owe it to my marriage. 

Sorry, If you were looking forward to it.    I was.

'Til next time...
